metadata.title: Discovering and Connecting to Nix Devices

inlineContent.text: Regardless of device type, each unique Nix device can be represented by an object that conforms to the
protocol. To obtain instances of the device object, they need to first be discovered using the
. They can also be recalled at a later time directly using their
property (for Bluetooth connected devices only).
The
implements the
protocol and searches for nearby Nix devices using Bluetooth. On macOS, the
will also report devices connected via USB. Scanner events are reported via:
Delegate which must be specified when initializing the
Reports when the scanner initializes, starts, and stops searching for devices
Closure which is called by the scanner each time that an
instance has been found
Note that this will be called both when a new device is found and when the RSSI/signal strength of a previously discovered device has changed.
It is possible to use the
parameter as a means to uniquely identify discovered devices.
Do not hold reference to stale
instances; use the most recently reported device instance when connecting to a device later.
Devices can only be discovered or recalled while your SDK licence is in an
state; the current value is available via
. Only device types supported by your license can be discovered and connected; the current list of allowed types is available via
To use the
Initialize the scanner and check its state in
After a successful initialization, the state will be
If the state is
, check
for further details.
If the scanner has initialized successfully, the scanner can be started using
By default, the scanner will search for a period
, but this interval can be overridden by providing an argument for
Discovered devices will be reported via a
closure. At this stage, it is valid to check a limited number of parameters:
: Device identifier string
: Device signal strength (-127 to 0). Will be 0 for USB connected devices
: Indicates whether the device was found via Bluetooth or USB connection
: Indicates the specific device type
: Full name of the device (e.g. ‘Nix Spectro 2’)
The device search will run for the specified duration, after which
is called. The device search can also be manually stopped using
To recall a specific Bluetooth connected device in a later app session, you can use
. This will run the
searching for a specific device by its identifier, calling back only once when the device is first found.

inlineContent.text: Once an
instance has been obtained, a connection can be opened by calling
. Connection state changes are provided via a
Implement the
protocol in your class
Stop the
before opening a connection, if still running.
It is safe to call
at any time, even if already stopped
Start the connection process using
The connection process is asynchronous and
will return immediately. If a connection activity indicator is shown, it can be shown immediately before calling this method.
A call to
will always result in either the
or
event being triggered.
Device operations are not possible until the
callback is received (successful connection)
If the connection process fails,
will be called with an appropriate status code indicating the cause of the error.
will also be called later whenever the device is disconnected. This can occur normally (i.e. - if the host device calls
), or abnormally (i.e. - if the connection is dropped due to an error or low Bluetooth signal strength).
Your license is linked to a specific allocation of Nix devices and will not operate with devices from another allocation.
At connection time, the SDK will read an allocation code stored on the Nix device and compare to the license information.
If this check does not pass, the SDK will contact a Nix authentication server to check if that device serial number is authorized.
If the device cannot be authenticated (i.e. – an unknown allocation code was found and an internet connection is unavailable), the device will be disconnected with the status
The internet connection is required only once every 30 days – once authorized, this status is saved, and connections can be made offline for this time period.
When the user has finished using the device, the connection can be closed using

code: // Device instance found by the DeviceScanner:
// Device properties can now be queried
// Handle status codes here, if desired in your application
// At a minimum should check for ERROR_UNAUTHORIZED status (see notes)
// Device not authorized for this license UUID
// There is an issue with the LicenseManager
// Connection to Nix device timed out
// External power has been connected or disconnected
// Device instance found by the DeviceScanner
// Device properties can now be queried
// Handle status codes here, if desired in your application
// At a minimum should check for ERROR_UNAUTHORIZED status (see notes)
// Device not authorized for this license UUID
// There is an issue with the LicenseManager
// Connection to Nix device timed out
NSLog(@"Battery level has updated to %@", newState);
// External power has been connected or disconnected
NSLog(@"External power connected is now %@", stateString);

Starts a search for a specific Nix device using Bluetooth. The search will run until the specified device is found, or until
elapses, whichever is shorter. Invoked with a
result when a search times out and device was not found.

instance on a connection state change, battery state change, or external power state change.
Stops a Bluetooth search if one is currently running.

The device connection attempt was cancelled because the specified device was not authorized for this build of the Nix SDK. Check that the device allocation code and/or serial number is expected to be authorized for this build.

Class used to manage the license for the Nix Universal SDK. Members of this class are not instantiated or accessed directly. Access to a single shared instance is provided via static methods and properties.
